italy's top leaders are doing the same
thing and the european union is watching
closely anxiety was very high in italy
on monday when it looked like italy
might be the next country to be attacked
by speculators who are concerned about
its high debt and political instability
now political instability is really
nothing new for Italy but it's rare for
there to be a European country where the
finance minister and the Prime Minister
seemed to be so at odds the tensions
between Berlusconi and Tremonti they
really embody classic tensions between
politics and economics Berlusconi has
not wanted to pass any measures that are
politically unpopular like raising taxes
whereas Tremonti who's seen as the
guardian of fiscal rigour knows that
Italy has to slash a lot of money from
its public sector in order to keep its
deficit down one of the things we're
seeing in this crisis in Europe is that
local politics are no longer local on
Sunday German Chancellor Angela Merkel
talked to Berlusconi and I think the
people i talked to indicate that
Berlusconi is increasingly aware of the
pressure of the tensions of the problems
Italy is facing and everyone seems to
think that the Italian government will
rally in the next few weeks and pass
this budget so that the pressure on
italy from speculators they hope will
lift when Derek Jeter reached the 3000
hit milestone all eyes turned to the man
who caught the ball and then returned it
this is John Leland metro reporter for
The New York Times when Christian Lopez
attended the yankee game on Saturday he
probably didn't expect that he would be
the one to catch Derek Jeter's 3000th
hit and walk out with over seventy
thousand dollars worth of merchandise he
probably also didn't expect they did owe
the tax man on his windfall but here he
is getting to meet the captain after he
caught the ball the 23 year old mobile
phone salesman was whisked away by
security guards and asked how much he
wanted for it he turned it like I'm not
going to be the person to take it away
from Lopez wound up with four seats in
the Champions suite for the rest of the
seasons home games and any playoff and
World Series game along with three bats
three balls and two jerseys all signed
by Derek Jeter the hall was worth about
seventy thousand dollars but he could
have made a lot more souvenirs like the
Jeter home run can be very valuable in
2006 San Francisco man named Andrew
orbit sir who ended up with Barry Bonds
record-breaking 715 home run sold the

twenty thousand dollars so not only did
Lopez get less money but now he may have
to pay taxes totaling tens of thousands
of dollars there have been incidents
like this before Oprah once gave out

afterwards the IRS came and demanded
